ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned all about naval weapons systems and how they work

Learned extensively about the mechanics of sonar, radar, fundamentals in weapons systems and tactical guides/tools that aid military operations. Additionally, covered topics important to national security at a comprehensive level (I.e cyber security and types of infiltration).
Weapons systems that are used in the Navy
Learned a lot about the weapon systems (guns, missiles, aircraft detection, radar, sonar) that the Navy's ships, aircraft, and submarines use to detect the enemy.

I learned a LOT about the basics of Naval Systems. Almost everything I learned from scratch, and a lot of it was really cool and all of it will be helpful out in the fleet I'm sure. I learned some basics about a variety of types of weapons systems, night vision, radar and sonar, cyber, etc. I have zero engineering background and my last physics course was freshman year of high school; I had to do some initial work on my own to catch up, but I would say it was well worth it and now I'm extra excited to see and work with these systems in the real world outside of the classroom. I would also say that LT Barszowski explained everything very well and very clearly, and someone without a STEM background can manage this course and get a lot out of it.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: cool material, nice teacher
Weaknesses: tests were too much memorization

Strengths: clear expectations, fair grading, good slides and visual mediums. 
Weaknesses: format of lecture was same every time, but instructor delivers with equal enthusiasm.
Really long powerpoint lecture were difficult to follow and continue to pay attention to

Strengths: super engaging material
Weaknesses: LT Barszowski does not go through any practice problems, which makes taking the midterm and tests difficult. In the future, please include many practice problems and go over them in class.

We covered a huge amount of material. LT Barszowski explained everything really well! Things were explained for someone with a non-STEM background to be able to understand, and LT Barszowski was able to answer a whole bunch of questions when we wanted to get into more specifics beyond the learning objectives. I really learned a lot and am very happy with the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Maybe more discussions?  Like if we had a project to do in place of an exam
I think the zoom sharing was effective and that the instructor was very good with making the test convertible to an online format, with diagrams, bubble-ins and short responses.

LT Barszowski did a great job running the class and getting student engagement. We covered all the learning objectives and were able to ask lots of questions. She also was very flexible and very available for office hours, and I learned a lot there too.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Only if they have to take it for NROTC
I recommend this course to all those interested in learning the principles and fundamentals that go into the physical security systems and best practices in weapons.
Required for Navy
If you are interested in weapons systems in the Navy, take this course! I learned things I never knew about.

I would recommend to students interested in learning about the material on the syllabus. We got a really solid overview of all the topics, and we were able to ask questions and go into depth into topics in class and in office hours. It is a solid course for students to learn about these topics without needing a STEM background, but to learn them well. For students entering the Navy, I am very happy with what I learned and thing I have a solid foundation from which to learn more before hitting the fleet; it is also a solid foundation from which to do more reading independently from some of the more technical material from the USNI reading materials. LT Barszowski goes out of her way to make sure everyone is happy with their understanding of the material.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom review sessions
none
Virtual lecture, but with so few people we were able and encouraged to ask questions and have a discussion about certain ideas and systems similar to a virtual seminar format.
